abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, although institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Lessons provide some
            insight on the experience of this operation. By and large, a
            Social Fund is an effective tool for providing timely
            development assistance in post-conflict situations, given
            its characteristics and delivery system allow for fast, and
            direct disbursement of funds which significantly reduce
            difficulties following the end of a conflict. Fund
            disbursement is relatively fast because of operational, and
            institutional arrangements, i.e., minimum channels of
            approval; and, direct contracting. Moreover, being an
            autonomous entity, Social Funds can minimize political
            interference, and allow for the processing of subprojects,
            based on agreed and transparent sets of rules. However, and
            given that social preparation, and technical capacity
            building activities enhance the project investments'
            sustainability, awareness-raising and capacity-building
            interventions during the early stage of subproject
            implementation are critical for the effective operation and
            maintenance (O&M) of subproject investments. Thus,
            nongovernmental organizations and other service providers
            should be contracted early on for the provision of training
            and technical assistance, balanced carefully vis-a-vis the
            need for tangible investments on the ground. Furthermore,
            while participation and commitment of local government units
            is crucial, potential risks of such involvement however,
            also poses challenges: such involvement facilitates
            technical, and financial support to subproject application,
            construction and O&M arrangements, but there is a
            potential danger of inappropriate political influence,
            especially where there is still enmity between participating
            groups. These risks, however, can be mitigated by fully
            adhering to a set of transparent rules and procedures,
            implemented under flexible, and clearly defined
            community-demand parameters.
